title: Opening Keynote
abstract: Apollo's Matt Debergalis will kick off GraphQL Summit with his Keynote address.
name: Matt Debergalis

title: The obligatory hooks talk
abstract: Let's talk about React and GraphQL! With all the new changes in React, we would expect some changes in the API we use for all our data needs, right? Let's dive through some live coding and see how we can switch to hooks with React and Apollo.
name: Sara Vieira

title: Extending GraphQL APIs with Durable Functions
abstract: Durable Functions are orchestrated serverless functions that keep track of state even after execution has completed. Therefore, you can get the value of this state over time. This is powerful for handling stateful computation ‚Äî you can lift such computations out of your GraphQL API logic, abstract them into durable functions, and reuse them since they are fundamentally functions.
name: Christian Nwamba

title: Migrating to Apollo at Airbnb
abstract: You've heard that Apollo & GraphQL are amazing technologies that can help your organization build faster. But, what about all of the existing code that relies on REST endpoints? In this talk, we'll show how we migrated to Apollo at Airbnb. We'll cover our use of TypeScript, incrementally adopting GraphQL in our React + Redux codebase, and lessons learned along the way to help you make a similar transition at your organization.
name: Brie Bunge

title: EthQL: Using GraphQL on the Ethereum Blockchain
abstract: EthQL is a project aimed at improving and standardizing a GraphQL schema for the Ethereum blockchain. GraphQL brings developers a more efficient and expressive interface to interact with blockchain data.
name: Kris Shinn

title: Intuit API: Caching at the Edge
abstract: Learn how Intuit uses GraphQL Service Orchestration and Caching to handle hundreds of services and serve millions of Customers.
name: Philip Russell

title: Client-side GraphQL at scale
abstract: We‚Äôll cover the testing, monitoring, and performance tricks needed to build a client-side app with hundreds of GraphQL operations.
name: Chris Sauv√©

title: The state of GraphQL in Python
abstract: What's the current state of GraphQL in Python? This talk will be a comparison between them, we'll be particularly looking into the following libraries: Graphene (the "oldest" and most popular one), Ariadne, Tartiflette, and Strawberry (the one I'm working on).
name: Patrick Arminio

title: Query Analysis Reboot
abstract: This talk will focus on using data to drive decisions; or how your users can help you better understand your own API by leveraging data pipelines and tracing tools.
name: Claire Knight

title: Efficient end-to-end testing with Puppeteer and GraphQL snapshots
abstract: Learn how to speed up client-side end-to-end tests by automatically recording server responses and using the snapshots to speed-up subsequent test runs.
name: Sebastian Scholl

title: GraphQL Search
abstract: Learn how we are able to search across our graph by leveraging existing graph edges to automatically build and maintain search indices.
name: Artem Shtatnov

title: Rust and GraphQL: A match made in heaven
abstract: Rust = awesome. GraphQL = awesome. GraphQL + Rust = 2awesome. Rust has some unique features that make it ideally suited for building GraphQL clients and servers. Learn why you should rewrite (mostly) everything in Rust!
name: Christian Legnitto

title: Cache All the Things!
abstract: Caching is hard. This is a talk about how we approached the problem at Trulia and implemented Backend and Frontend caching for GraphQL.
name: Aditi Garg

title: Cache All the Things!
abstract: Caching is hard. This is a talk about how we approached the problem at Trulia and implemented Backend and Frontend caching for GraphQL.
name: Sandosh Vasudevan

title: Exposing Salesforce data through GraphQL
abstract: Salesforce is the largest relational enterprise data store in the world. This talk explores how to unlock the data inside Salesforce using GraphQL and make it easy to build front-end customer-facing apps on top of it using Apollo Client.
name: Andrei Anisimov

title: SDL as an Artifact: Code-First Schemas in TS/JS
abstract: Schema-first (SDL) development is common in the JS ecosystem, yet isn‚Äôt in most other languages. Why? What if we challenged this ‚Äúbest practice‚Äù with a new approach - a library with a declarative API and full type safety out of the box - without needing manual type-annotation (even in JS)!
name: Tim Griesser

title: Components as Data: A Cross Platform GraphQL Powered Component API
abstract: Move your API's "Decouple line" further towards front end and you can get some cool features: Server side A/B testing and Feature Flagging, centralized business logic, and simpler frontend apps. Components as Data is an API design pattern that enables these features and pairs perfectly with GraphQL's type system.
name: Luke Herrington

title: Building a high-performance realtime GraphQL API on existing databases and data sources
abstract: I will talk about the approach we took at Hasura of building a GraphQL API that can leverage an existing database. You'll learn how we built a declarative authorization system and addressed the n+1 database query problem. With GraphQL making it easy to ‚Äújoin data‚Äù across tables, I‚Äôll also talk about how we can ‚Äújoin data‚Äù between a table and an existing API.
name: Tanmai Gopal

title: Caching & GraphQL: Setting the Story Straight
abstract: Put the words caching and GraphQL in the same sentence, and without a doubt you've got a debate going. It's time to debunk some myths, shine some light and explore the world of caching & GraphQL together.
name: Marc-Andr√© Giroux

title: Optimistic UI: Predicting the Future
abstract: Optimistic UI is a powerful tool to help your UI respond to expected changes without the need for a page refresh or loading component.
name: Kenny Hammerlund

title: Transforming customer experiences and your organization with GraphQL
abstract: Through storytelling, Dan Boerner and Jim Gust will share the expected and unexpected ways that GraphQL is transforming how Expedia Group creates seamless customer experiences across their front-end platforms. Along the way, they will share hard fought lessons and mistakes during their journey selling the promise of GraphQL, keeping momentum building beyond the initial POC team, and scaling a graph that spans the many services and teams.
name: Jim Gust

title: How We Scaled GraphQL at The New York Times
abstract: The New York Times delivered around 5 billion GraphQL responses last month, but only a fraction of those were executed by the GraphQL server application.  This session will go into detail about how we use Fastly to deliver all this data and the challenges that we faced along the way.
name: James Lawrie

title: GraphQL Tools are easy or how to write one in less than 100 lines
abstract: It‚Äôs an exciting time for the GraphQL ecosystem. New tools appear almost every day and you may have a few ideas for your own. But working with queries and the type system looks scary at first. In my talk, I will prove the opposite and demonstrate how you can write a useful tool in <100 lines of code.
name: Ivan Goncharov

title: From Vuex to Apollo state management: GitLab journey
abstract: Do you need an external local state management if you decide to use GraphQL with Apollo Client? Let's see how we're moving from Vuex to Apollo state management at GitLab.
name: Natalia Tepluhina

title: Apollo GraphQL Server per field caching mechanism for an object based database
abstract: GraphQL offers loads of possibilities, one of them is directives. We can use directives to apply a server side per field caching mechanism which allows us to fetch less data at each request if we are using an object based database.
name: Bo≈°tjan Cigan

title: Building a faster checkout experience at PayPal with GraphQL
abstract: At PayPal, we are rebuilding our checkout experience from the ground up. The most important and logical problem we are solving is to make the experience super fast. Come hear our story on how we leveraged GraphQL server to efficiently present varied regional payment experiences to people all around the globe.
name: Vishakha Singh

title: Sorting and filtering in GraphQL
abstract: GraphQL lets you select fields out of the box. Relay and Apollo introduce standard patterns for paginating results. There are however no obvious patterns for sorting and filtering results. Allow me to present a few reusable solutions.
name: J√©r√©mie Astori

title: GraphQL in Every Language
abstract: GraphQL clients and servers exist in many different programming languages ‚Äî not just JavaScript! Join me for a journey into GraphQL in (almost) every language under the sun.
name: Jon Wong

title: Building the one-graph together
abstract: SAP Concur is moving from multiple graphs to a unified graph and one of the greatest challenges we faced is the coordination needed between dozens of teams and product areas. I'll share the practices we used to strike a balance between creating a coherent graph and moving quickly.
name: Sam Parsons

title: Building offline first apps with GraphQL & Apollo
abstract: Offline first apps have a unique set of challenges to keep them fully functional even in offline mode. On top of that, GraphQL based apps need new ways of solving these challenges. In this talk, I will share my experience with implementing offline first app with GraphQL & Apollo.
name: Kiran Kumar Abburi

title: Resolve Info Deep Dive
abstract: Each GraphQL resolver is passed an object called the resolve info argument. This object contains information about the schema and query and can be used to construct database queries at runtime inside the resolver.
name: William Lyon

title: Fixing Airplanes with GraphQL
abstract: Embraer, the third largest manufacturer of civil aircraft, is using GraphQL to improve air travel for everyone. Come see how Embraer uses GraphQL to help airlines, mechanics, and others coordinate and collaborate to fix broken airplanes before they cause your important flight to be delayed.
name: Dom Kiva-Meyer

title: Configuration driven Data as a Service gateway with GraphQL
abstract: In this talk, you‚Äôll learn about techniques used to build a scalable GraphQL based data gateway with the capability to dynamically on-board various new data sources. They include runtime schema evolution and resolver wiring, abstract resolvers, auto GraphQL schema generation from other schema types, and construction of appropriate cache key-values.
name: Noriaki Tatsumi

title: A Tinder Love Story: How we created our WordPress blog in React instead of PHP
abstract: Don't dust off that PHP for Dummies book just yet! Learn how Tinder created a Wordpress website entirely in React using GraphQL + GatsbyJS üî• Bring your humor, forget the PHP & let's have nerdy fun together!
name: Kyle Boss

title: Real World Graphene: lessons learned from building a GraphQL API on top of a Django app
abstract: Adding a full-fledged GraphQL API on top of a Django app using Graphene can be daunting. I want to share a few techniques that bring consistency in the implementation and shape of API, solve common API design issues, and overcome some of the framework‚Äôs shortcomings.
name: Marcin Gƒôbala

title: Oh the Connections You‚Äôll Make...With Apollo Federation
abstract: Apollo Federation is an exciting new architecture which allows organizations to expose one data graph for all of their distributed data. This architecture also opens up exciting opportunities for building a data graph on top of previously unconnected third party APIs.
name: Matt Dionis

title: Game Of Types: A Song Of GraphQL And TypeScript
abstract: Treating our GraphQL schema as the single source of truth for our types and generating TypeScript definitions from it, we diminish the risk of duplication and divergence between the two type systems.
name: Steven Musumeche

title: State Management in GraphQL using React Hooks & Apollo
abstract: This talks walks through how to use React Hooks in maintaining state while using GraphQL.
name: Shruti Kapoor

title: The future of GraphQL tooling and DX
abstract: Learn how OneGraph has built custom tooling such as their Explorer, Code exporter, query doctor, intelligent variable form for GraphiQL, intelligent historical-based mocking for an API, etc.
name: Daniel Woelfel

title: Expose your Kafka with GraphQL
abstract: I will demo and show some code how especially GraphQL subscriptions can be used with Kafka to create reactive applications. I will also give some pointers what you might run into when running in production.
name: Gerard Klijs

title: GitLab: down the GraphQL rabbit hole
abstract: GitLab is on its way to GraphQL General Availability in early 2020. This journey raises multiple challenges from "classical" security to overall question how to provide best developer experience migrating huge existing codebase on new rails :). We are going to share both our own answers
name: Natalia Tepluhina

title: GitLab: down the GraphQL rabbit hole
abstract: GitLab is on its way to GraphQL General Availability in early 2020. This journey raises multiple challenges from "classical" security to overall question how to provide best developer experience migrating huge existing codebase on new rails :). We are going to share both our own answers
name: Illya Klymov

title: A Treatise on State
abstract:
State management is a hard problem - which is why we have an ever-growing number of tools to help us. But can we get it right without truly understanding what "state" is?

Enter a treatise on state: a study of the different types of state we manage, how to think about each, and how to get them playing nicely together.
name: Jed Watson

title: Scaling GraphQL Beyond a Backend for Frontend
abstract: How do you scale your GraphQL API beyond a single consumer? This talk will discuss transitioning a client-specific GraphQL layer into a universal graph for multiple consumers.
name: Michelle Garrett

title: Scaling GraphQL Beyond a Backend for Frontend
abstract: How do you scale your GraphQL API beyond a single consumer? This talk will discuss transitioning a client-specific GraphQL layer into a universal graph for multiple consumers.
name: Faduma Mohammed

title: useSubscription: A GraphQL Game Show
abstract: A real-time game show brought to you by GraphQL Subscriptions. In this highly interactive presentation, you'll become a contestant on a game show that is powered by GraphQL. Along the way, we will take a deep dive into subscription implementation, state management, and solutions for scaling real-time GraphQL applications.
name: Alex Banks

title: How to talk to your boss about GraphQL
abstract: For most folks, the technical ROI on GraphQL is apparent. But how do you explain that to people at work who think more in spreadsheets than they do in graphs?
name: Brandon Paquette

title: Simple caching, made difficult.
abstract: Let's dive into the journey towards successfully synchronizing the TTL of your data with the cache expiration in a GraphQL request.
name: Eric Baer

title: Adding Typescript to your GraphQL server
abstract: Considering moving your existing GraphQL server to Typescript, but don‚Äôt know where to start? This talk will walk you through all the basics: from adding Typescript to your server, convincing your team and the migration strategy that will eventually get you there.
name: Zhifan Li

title: How do you get changes made to GraphQL?
abstract: In this talk, you'll learn how to pitch for a change to the GraphQL specs, or first-party projects.
name: Orta

title: What About the Database? How to Write Efficient Queries for GraphQL Resolvers
abstract: When writing GraphQL servers, we often place a lot of emphasis on how to craft good resolvers. However, we don't often think about how to create good database queries to furnish the data for those resolvers. Let's look at how it's easy to fall into the trap of writing inefficient database queries and how we can use GraphQL itself to solve this problem.
name: Ryan Chenkie

title: I heart GraphQL (and Kotlin)
abstract: In this talk, you'll hear from a Kotlin fanboy who wants to show you how he built his GraphQL APIs.
name: Rohit Basu

title: LinkedIn's Economic Graph on GraphQL
abstract: LinkedIn is leveraging GraphQL to enable easier addition and access of entities in the Economic Graph for first party products. The talk will present LinkedIn‚Äôs vision for modelling entities (like member, activity, company etc.), defining privacy rules and enabling a consistent access experience across online, nearline and offline environments.
name: Gopal Holla

title: Transforming customer experiences and your organization with GraphQL
abstract: Through storytelling, Dan Boerner and Jim Gust will share the expected and unexpected ways that GraphQL is transforming how Expedia Group creates seamless customer experiences across their front-end platforms. Along the way, they will share hard fought lessons and mistakes during their journey selling the promise of GraphQL, keeping momentum building beyond the initial POC team, and scaling a graph that spans the many services and teams.
name: Dan Boerner

title: The GraphQL developer experience
abstract: Hear about how the shift from legacy APIs to GraphQL can spark joy and productivity in developers. See Danielle walk through a live demo of connecting backend services to UI with a seamless programming model that extends from server to client using Apollo GraphQL and React
name: Danielle Man

title: The agile schema evolution and graph management
abstract: As GraphQL usage increases in an organization, Evans will demonstrate why it‚Äôs important for teams to practice agile schema development and iteratively evolve their schema over time
name: Evans Hauser

title: Digging into the Apollo iOS SDK
abstract: Learn about the what and why of recent updates to ApolloGraphQL‚Äôs Swift iOS SDK, including integrating with Swift Package Manager, and get a preview of our updated code generation process.
name: Ellen Shapiro

title: Migrating Apollo‚Äôs Data Graph from Schema-stitching to Federation
abstract: Find out more about the infrastructure that powers Apollo Graph Manager and how we have evolved the Graph Manager Data Graph (ooh, that‚Äôs meta) from monolith to schema-stitching to federation. Learn from the mistakes we made, the patterns that ultimately worked, and the way we took advantage of federation to enhance both our product delivery process and graph performance
name: Adam Zionts

title: Fine-Tuning Apollo Client Caching for Your Data Graph
abstract: While cache normalization is essential for reactive updates in a single-page application, and Apollo Client provides powerful default normalization behavior, not all parts of all applications need to remain up-to-date at all times, and common patterns like pagination can benefit from custom normalization implementations. Learn how to customize the Apollo Client cache to suit your weirdest data modeling and reactivity needs, using the all-new cache API in Apollo Client 3.0.
name: Ben Newman

title: The Architecture of Federation
abstract: Apollo Federation brought a new architecture to GraphQL and a new way of thinking about how to design and build a schema, but what does it mean for how your team builds a data graph? In this talk you will learn about the architectural principles behind federation and see how you can implement a well designed and structured data graph using Apollo.
name: Jeff Hampton

title: Protecting your GraphQL server in production using best practices and tooling in the Apollo GraphQL Platform
abstract: Come learn best practices for protecting your GraphQL server in production from bad actors and shipping breaking changes. We‚Äôll start with the basics and then show how we can use the Apollo GraphQL Platform to prevent shipping breaking schema changes that could bring down your graph; even for a federated graph! Then we‚Äôll look at how we can create an operation safelist for your graph using the Apollo CLI and Apollo Operation Registry. This talk will primarily cover Apollo Server use cases, but some of the basics will apply to any GraphQL server.
name: Michael Watson
